The number one reason that Alaskans over

630.text:
is because they've fallen. Most of these

634.text:
where the essential activities of daily
living like bathing,

641.text:
happen everyday. Now let's look at one

649.text:
that have been implemented in an already

The first thing that we notice is that
the entire bathroom floor

656.text:

Unlike tile, this type of flooring is low

666.text: risk of falling. The flooring coves

714.text:
as they transfer into the tub. One simple

719.text:

723.text:

726.text:

731.text:
The trick is to get them in the right

736.text:

740.text:

743.text:

747.text:
Another diagonal or horizontal grab bar

752.text: and down from the bathtub floor,

754.text:
toilet, or from a shower chair. When you're

759.text:
you can install them wherever they
provide the most assistance without

762.text:
having to comply with federal
regulations

764.text:
such as the Americans with Disabilities
Act. When possible the tub in an older

771.text:
should be replaced with a walk-in shower

775.text:
This type of shower often fits into the
same space as a pre-existing bathtub,

780.text: but it has no raised barrier between the bathroom floor

784.text:
and the shower. This level junction
connecting the shower floor and the

790.text:
means wheelchair users can roll in and

795.text:
potential tripping hazard. Showers are

Older tubs

804.text:

flat surface

811.text:
for standing on and the curved sides make
it difficult to be sure where the sides

817.text:
Tubs with textured, flat floors and distinct

829.text:
16 to 21 inches for most people, makes a

835.text:
and rest on as they get in and out of

bathers

841.text:

one

Large,

903.text:

967.text:
The best configuration for toilet grab

972.text:
This allows older people to use their

977.text: and lower themselves on and off

982.text:

If possible, putting grab bars on
both sides

989.text:
that allows for compensation of both
